Good afternoon,
 
Harry Smith here filling in while Katie’s on assignment.
  
 
After a week of floods and fires across the United States, Catalina Island off Los Angeles has become
  the latest wildfire victim. Throughout the night, thousands of residents and
  visitors fled the island’s main town, which was under evacuation order.
  Bill Whitaker will report on the devastating blaze and citizens’
  dramatic nighttime escapes. 
 
Meanwhile, Sharyl Attkisson is on Capitol Hill with
  some exclusive information about what might be the best chance for all sides
  to work out a last-ditch immigration reform deal.
 
On the state level, legislation is being considered
  in several states that could affect the lives of teens and the
  tech-dependent. Sandra Hughes will report that Washington
  state and New Jersey
  could both ban text messaging while driving. Considering the statistics
  – teenagers say text messaging is their biggest driving distraction
  – more states could follow suit. 
 
It is graduation day at Virginia Tech, and
  today’s ceremonies will be part commencement and part remembrance.
  Sharyn Alfonsi is on campus and will have the story.
 
There is also a unique graduation story at Fort Hays State University
  in Kansas. For
  Assignment America, Steve Hartman will introduce you to one student there who
  followed the advice “it’s never too late to follow your dreams.”
  Now – at more than 90 years old – she’s becoming the
  country’s oldest person to be graduated by a college. 
 
Join us tonight for this and more.
